Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Biventricular Pacing on Hemodynamics Post-Cardiopulmonary Bypass

Participants.evidence: 30 patients with a mean ejection fraction of 35%±15% and mean QRS duration of 119±24 ms, undergoing coronary bypass and/or valve surgery

Intervention.evidence: randomised to receive either optimized biventricular pacing or atrial pacing at a matched heart rate, with sinus rhythm serving as a control

Objective.evidence: This trial investigates its sustained impact on mean arterial pressure (MAP) following chest closure.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the change in MAP, assessed over 30-second intervals.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence, and allocation was concealed.

Blinding.evidence: Outcome assessors were blinded to group assignments.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Optimized biventricular pacing resulted in a 4% increase in MAP compared to sinus rhythm (78.5±2.4 vs 75.1±2.4 mm Hg; P=0.002) and a 3% increase compared to atrial pacing (76.4±2.7 mm Hg; P=0.017).

Harms.evidence: No adverse events were reported during the study.
